awd_titl_txt: One Community, One Challenge: Pop-Up STEAM Studios
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative resources for use in a variety of settings. The project will develop and research, as a feasibility study, a series of art-inclusive, pop-up Science, Art, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEAM) makerspaces in a high-poverty, primarily rural county in Oklahoma. A makerspace is a collaborative work space inside a library, school or other community space for making, learning, exploring and sharing that uses high tech to low tech tools. The makerspaces will be temporary workshops that are developed through a community planning process that assesses the needs and interests of citizen stakeholders. Scientists, artists and other experts will work together with the community to design a series of thematic pop-up makerspace sessions. The project builds a collaborative infrastructure and capacity for small and rural communities by bringing together resource providers and experts to identify and design science-oriented challenges. Long-term benefits for participants include sustained focus on new approaches for civic engagement through STEAM-driven making which could foster new role identities pertaining to science and art. The project deliverables include: (1) a theoretically informed model to build a community's capacity to collaborate toward fostering civic engagement through science-oriented pop-up makerspaces, (2) Pop-Up STEAM Studio makerspaces, (3) training for pop-up facilitators, and (4) visual documentation panels and web-based digital stories to communicate progress and process.  

Project research will enhance knowledge-building of the process of developing a science-oriented community challenge that embraces STEAM and making. A key contribution of the proposed project will be the generation of insights into how community members establish consensus around the joint goal of designing, documenting, and facilitating integrated art and science making activities to address and communicate the challenge. Research will focus on the roles participants take when engaging in the making process through an identity-based model of motivated action. Analysis of advisory board meeting artifacts and focus group data will allow the researchers to identify processes of negotiation and consensus building at the collective level and in relation to each issue to which the group attends. Emergent themes (such as negotiation, shared learning, idea or project revisions, diverse perspectives coming to consensus, etc.) will be examined across individual and group units of analysis, from all data sources, and through the congruent theoretical lenses of role identity theory and negotiated learning pedagogy. The research outcomes should inform efforts to build infrastructure and capacity of community resources by providing a model for developing collaborative pop-up makerspaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This Pilots and Feasibility project, entitled “One Community, One Challenge: Pop-Up STEAM Studios” (Award #1906473) focuses on the design, development, and evaluation of an informal science education (ISE) series of art-inclusive, pop-up makerspaces in a high-poverty, primarily rural county in Oklahoma.  Informed by museum pop-ups, our STEAM Studios are temporary workshops in a designated locale based on needs and desires of citizen stakeholders and informed by experts that focus on relationships, sharing, and communication with the capacity to cross sometimes siloed boundaries. The project innovation extends and adapts the pop-up concept through two participatory, socially-inclusive approaches: One Book, One Community, a national public library program, and the participatory pedagogy of negotiated learning. The project goals included promoting a participatory culture to leverage community funds of knowledge, individually and collectively, to address community-identified and designed challenges. We also used digital stories, or visual documentation panels, to uncover the Learning Practices of Making that occurred during the popup STEAM Studio events. For this final report, we provide a brief overview of the project through the goals and deliverables in this section. 


The major goals of the project were to (1) develop an identity-based model of building a community’s capacity to collaborate towards engaging this civic group in identifying the makerspace theme, (2) use an participatory approach to design and implement the pop-up makerspaces, and (3) explore how people engage in Learning Process of Making in the pop-up makerspaces.


Grant activities with the advisory board were slated to begin just as the COVID-19 pandemic hit. Due to this, advisory board meetings were delayed and moved online. The advisory board members, perhaps influenced by the pandemic, focused on relationships, sharing, and communication, which led to an overarching theme of Common Ground. Due to continuing pandemic restrictions, the initial pop-up makerspace shifted into a take-home challenge box exploring wind power and turbines, building on a downtown collaborative project between engineers and artists that had been neglected for a while. The challenge was to use a model to build and test a wind turbine redesigning the blades for both aesthetics and power. We gave out 173 boxes to interested people at county libraries, an arts center, and resource centers, but found that it was difficult to get people to interact with us online after they received the boxes.


Our next challenge, featuring a solar lantern design, occurred once pandemic restrictions eased. We were able to conduct in-person pop-up makerspace events at the local arts center, botanic garden, parks, county libraries and family resource centers. The events were well-attended and led to a lot of data on the process of making and micro-identity shifts. We developed 33 digital stories revealing the making process of participants across the county. We also learned that walk-up events such as those at the botanic garden and parks were not as fruitful for data collection as events where people made a plan to attend. 


Our final challenge was stories in soil, a science-forward challenge of soil filtration paired with an arts-forward challenge of painting with soil pigments. We hosted pop-up events at the local arts center, county libraries, a county family resource center, and a Osher Lifelong Learning Institute meeting which led to another 15 digital stories revealing the process of making. 


Early results include the development and publication of an identity-based collaborative model for fostering civic engagement through a community science challenge (International Journal of Complexity in Education, 2021). We also have 4 conference proceedings and 8 conference presentations over the life of the grant. We are currently analyzing data on micro-identity shifts, designing the pop-up challenges, and participants’ process of making in order to write additional manuscripts. In addition to determining which Learning Practices of Making are easily identified through digital stories, we also uncovered a finding of participant satisfaction in the making process and products, even through missteps and mishaps. 


Broader Impacts. We worked toward advancing new approaches to and evidence-based understanding of the design and development of science and art learning in informal environments. The project built a collaborative infrastructure through a collaborative review of community assets, needs, and capacity for small and rural communities by bringing together resource providers and experts to identify and design arti-inclusive, science-oriented challenges. Documentation through digital stories helped to communicate processes and products in order to pique interest and invite engagement in community challenges, thus making science and art more accessible. Additionally, we are part of the Critically Relationality Alliance for Transformation (CRAFT) Network, and NSF sponsor network (Award # 2005898). This network supports equitable and interdisciplinary education through making in STEM and outside of STEM. They support new partnerships with community and school-based making to pursue common research questions. 




 


Last Modified: 12/13/2023
Modified by: Sheri E Vasinda
